repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

comment_data.body: Maybe it would be a good idea to create a separate `Encoding` enum type?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1876,7 +1876,7 @@ apply_text_document_edit({text_document_edit}, {index}, {offset_encoding})
       • {text_document_edit}  (`lsp.TextDocumentEdit`)
       • {index}               (`integer?`) Optional index of the edit, if from
                               a list of edits (or nil, if not from a list)
-      • {offset_encoding}     (`string?`)
+      • {offset_encoding}     (`'utf-8'|'utf-16'|'utf-32'?`)

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
      • {opts}?    (`table`) A table with the following fields:
```

Looks like the table is optional.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2038,20 +2031,38 @@ make_floating_popup_options({width}, {height}, {opts})
     Parameters: ~
       • {width}   (`integer`) window width (in character cells)
       • {height}  (`integer`) window height (in character cells)
-      • {opts}    (`table`) optional
-                  • offset_x (integer) offset to add to `col`
-                  • offset_y (integer) offset to add to `row`
-                  • border (string or table) override `border`
-                  • focusable (string or table) override `focusable`
-                  • zindex (string or table) override `zindex`, defaults to 50
-                  • relative ("mouse"|"cursor") defaults to "cursor"
-                  • anchor_bias ("auto"|"above"|"below") defaults to "auto"
-                    • "auto": place window based on which side of the cursor
-                      has more lines
-                    • "above": place the window above the cursor unless there
-                      are not enough lines to display the full window height.
-                    • "below": place the window below the cursor unless there
-                      are not enough lines to display the full window height.
+      • {opts}    (`table`) A table with the following fields:

comment_data.body: This should still be optional right?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2029,8 +1977,8 @@ end
 --- `textDocument/codeAction`, `textDocument/colorPresentation`,
 --- `textDocument/rangeFormatting`.
 ---
----@param window integer|nil: window handle or 0 for current, defaults to current
----@param offset_encoding "utf-8"|"utf-16"|"utf-32"|nil defaults to `offset_encoding` of first client of buffer of `window`
+---@param window integer window handle or 0 for current, defaults to current

comment_data.body: Do we have a convention around using 2 spaces after periods?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -66,6 +66,97 @@
 --- @field winnr integer
 --- @field winrow integer
 
+--- @class vim.quickfix.entry
+--- buffer number; must be the number of a valid buffer
+--- @field bufnr? integer
+---
+--- name of a file; only used when "bufnr" is not
+--- present or it is invalid.
+--- @field filename? string
+---
+--- name of a module; if given it will be used in
+--- quickfix error window instead of the filename.
+--- @field module? string
+---
+--- line number in the file
+--- @field lnum? integer
+---
+--- end of lines, if the item spans multiple lines
+--- @field end_lnum? integer
+---
+--- search pattern used to locate the error
+--- @field pattern? string
+---
+--- column number
+--- @field col? integer
+---
+--- when non-zero: "col" is visual column
+--- when zero: "col" is byte index
+--- @field vcol? integer
+---
+--- end column, if the item spans multiple columns
+--- @field end_col? integer
+---
+--- error number
+--- @field nr? integer
+---
+--- description of the error
+--- @field text? string
+---
+--- single-character error type, 'E', 'W', etc.
+--- @field type? string
+---
+--- recognized error message
+--- @field valid? boolean
+---
+--- custom data associated with the item, can be
+--- any type.
+--- @field user_data? any
+
+--- @class vim.fn.setqflist.what
+---
+--- quickfix list context. See |quickfix-context|
+--- @field context? table
+---
+--- errorformat to use when parsing text from
+--- "lines". If this is not present, then the
+--- 'errorformat' option value is used.
+--- See |quickfix-parse|
+--- @field efm? string
+---
+--- quickfix list identifier |quickfix-ID|
+--- @field id? integer
+--- index of the current entry in the quickfix
+--- list specified by "id" or "nr". If set to '$',
+--- then the last entry in the list is set as the
+--- current entry.  See |quickfix-index|
+--- @field idx? integer
+---
+--- list of quickfix entries. Same as the {list}
+--- argument.
+--- @field items? vim.quickfix.entry[]
+---
+--- use 'errorformat' to parse a list of lines and
+--- add the resulting entries to the quickfix list
+--- {nr} or {id}.  Only a |List| value is supported.

comment_data.body: There is an LSP type, but we don't render those into the docs so it opted to inline the values.

+      • {offset_encoding}     (`'utf-8'|'utf-16'|'utf-32'?`)

comment_data.body:
off-topic: should we be prefixing our "types" with underscore to signal that they may change at any time (or at least their names are not guaranteed to be stable, so a "nominal" reference could break in the future)?
```suggestion
      { 'list', '_nvim.quickfix.entry[]' },
```
Vim does; we don't (or shouldn't -- this isn't a 19th century American typewriter, for Pete's sake!)

comment_data.body: I don't think so. I'm not sure what problem that solves. There is a possibility that these types never change; If we add `__nvim_types` then it is more likely they will change. These types are only used for LSP and linting, so they are low risk.
Ok I'll update this to the 21st century to avoid a spacewars sequel.

comment_data.body: I mean if plugin authors start referencing the types defined in our meta files, then changing those types will "break" those consumers.

It's not been a problem for me and my plugins. It doesn't break the plugins, it just causes some diagnostics which are trivial to resolve.

Communicating to me that using these types _might_ change doesn't improve anything for me as a plugin author. I'm going to use them regardless, because the alternatives are much worse.

comment_regular_data.body: Someone just forgor about the `refactor` commit type. We'll fix it in post.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

labels.description: changes that are not features or bugfixes
labels.name: refactor
